intro: Leptochilus punctatus, commonly known as the spotted liverwort, is a small, non-vascular plant belonging to the family Porellaceae. It is characterized by its leafy, thalloid structure with a distinctive pattern of tubercles and punctate markings. This species typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rock crevices. Its reproductive structures include capsules that release spores, typical of bryophytes. Leptochilus punctatus is often found in temperate regions and plays a role in soil stabilization and microhabitat creation.
